title: South African president Ramaphosa to announce cabinet reshuffle
text: February 26, 2018 / 5:37 PM / Updated 2 minutes ago South African president Ramaphosa to announce cabinet reshuffle Reuters Staff 2 Min Read JOHANNESBURG (Reuters) - South African President Cyril Ramaphosa will announce a cabinet reshuffle at 1830 GMT on Monday, his office said in a short statement, but it was not clear whether this heralded a purge of allies of former president Jacob Zuma from the cabinet. Ramaphosa was sworn almost two weeks ago after Zuma reluctantly resigned his scandal-plagued presidency. Hailing a “new dawn” a day after his inauguration, the 65-year-old has promised to fight corruption, which had weakened the economy of Africa’s most industrialized nation, and to trim a bloated cabinet. Zuma, 75, stepped down on the orders of the ruling African National Congress (ANC) after nine years in office blighted by corruption, economic mismanagement and disputed appointments. He denies any wrongdoing. Speculation is mounting about whether Zuma-era Finance Minister Malusi Gigaba will keep his position. When asked about his job, Gigaba, who delivered the budget speech on Wednesday, has said he serves at the pleasure of the president. The statement from Ramaphosa’s office came minutes after news channels eNCA and SABC News reported that David Mabuza, deputy president of the ANC and Zweli Mkhize, the party’s former treasurer general, would be sworn as members of parliament. The eNCA channel also said former finance minister Nhlanhla Nene -- who was removed by Zuma -- would be sworn in as a lawmaker, alongside several other candidates. The ANC selects its cabinet ministers from among lawmakers in parliament. Parliamentary spokesman Moloto Mothapo said he did not have a list of ANC lawmakers to be sworn in. Ramaphosa said last week that he planned to screen the lifestyles of future government officials as he mulled the make-up of a new cabinet. Ramaphosa’s election as president, which was unopposed in the parliament, has prompted a wave of optimism among South Africans hungry for change after nine years of economic stagnation and corruption scandals. Reporting by Tiisetso Motsoeneng and James Macharia; Editing by Catherine Evans
